Not to be confused with Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, commonly abbreviated as "ISIS" ISIS ([MASK] System Implementation Supervisor) is an Operating System, created by Intel for their Intel Microprocessor Development System around 1976, and adopted as ISIS-II for systems with floppy drives.

ISIS-II has been distributed as part of the [MASK] Microprocessor Development System and includes standard operating system commands (copy, delete, dir, rename, format) and debugging software (assembler, linker and debugger for external debugging in developed device).

Shared Variables were first introduced by [MASK] (IBM) in their APL.SV software product in 1973, and are still available as of 2015, in APLs from IBM and Dyalog, for the operating systems Linux and Windows.
Many of the Shared Variable Processors available for [MASK] products were also written for Sharp APL, notably TSIO (called PJAM), AP124, AP126, and AP127.

Although Dyalog APL included an implementation of shared variables for communication with the now-deprecated Microsoft Windows Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE), it is interesting to note that only [MASK] continued to use Shared Variables as a means to supply new features to their versions of the APL2 language for non-mainframe computers.

Shared Variables were first introduced by International Business Machines Corporation ([MASK]) in their APL.SV software product in 1973, and are still available as of 2015, in APLs from IBM and Dyalog, for the operating systems Linux and Windows.
Following APL.SV, the [MASK] VS APL and APL2 program products also supported shared variables, as well as the IBM 5100 line of computers.

The Bonnell microarchitecture therefore represents a partial revival of the principles used in earlier [MASK] designs such as P5 and the i486, with the sole purpose of enhancing the performance per watt ratio.
[MASK]'s low-powered Bonnell microarchitecture employed in Atom processor cores also uses an in-order dual pipeline similar to P5.
The IBM Personal Computer Basic, commonly shortened to IBM BASIC, is a programming language first released by [MASK] with the IBM Personal Computer (model 5150) in 1981.
In addition to the features of an ANSI standard BASIC, the [MASK] versions offered support for the graphics and sound hardware of the IBM PC line.

Shinobi (Japanese: 忍 -SHINOBI-) is a side-scrolling action game produced by [MASK] originally released for the arcades in 1987.
